docs.lead_paragraph: Bush Defends Iraq Strategy; Shiites Execute 4 Men President Bush pushed back at critics who have urged that troops be withdrawn from Iraq, declaring, ''We will not lose our nerve.'' In Baghdad, Shiite vigilantes executed four men and hung their bodies from lampposts, as sectarian violence continued in Iraq. PAGES A12 AND A17 Some SAT's Not Rechecked A week after alerting colleges that about 4,000 students had been given wrong scores on the October SAT test, the College Board said that it had discovered that an additional 1,600 students who took that exam had not yet had their tests re-evaluated for errors. PAGE A21 To Sleep, Perchance to Eat The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to studies that describe how the drug's users sometimes sleepwalk into their kitchens and consume thousands of calories. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Pregnancy as a Conflict A theory that a mother and her fetus engage in an unconscious struggle over the nutrients she will supply it has been gaining support in recent years. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 Impact of a Newspaper Deal As the McClatchy Company announced that it would sell 12 of the 32 newspapers it was acquiring with its purchase of the Knight Ridder chain, there was joy and despair among Knight Ridder employees. Those at the papers being kept by McClatchy, including The Miami Herald, will be working for a family-controlled business with solid journalistic standards. But those at the papers to be sold, including The Philadelphia Inquirer, face continued uncertainty. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Maureen Stapleton Is Dead The actress, whose tough but vulnerable roles began in 1951 with Serafina in ''The Rose Tattoo'' (below, with Eli Wallach) and included an Oscar-winning portrayal of Emma Goldman, was 80. PAGE B9

docs.abstract: LuAnn Wierdsma letter on March 7 Cases column describing good works of hospital chaplin tells story of nurse who helped her cope with stillborn birth of baby girl
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     ''As Surgeons Clasped the Heart, He Reached for the Soul'' (Cases, March 7) brought back bittersweet memories of the birth of my first child, a stillborn daughter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnancy can be the most wonderful experience life has to offer. But it can also be dangerous. Around the world, an estimated 529,000 women a year die during pregnancy or childbirth. Ten million suffer injuries, infection or disability. To David Haig, an evolutionary biologist at Harvard, these grim statistics raise a profound puzzle about pregnancy.

headline.main: Silent Struggle: A New Theory of Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Dr David Haig, Harvard University evolutionary biologist, suggests that pregnancy and family relationships are physically and emotionally shaped by genetic conflict between parents and off-spring; explains how relationship between fetus and mother is power struggle for optimal survival; recent research on preeclampsia, which is published in journal Current Topics in Developmental Biology, supports Haig's evolutionary theories; photos; graph (M)
docs.snippet: A Harvard biologist argues that a mother and her unborn child engage in an unconscious struggle over the nutrients she will provide it.

docs.lead_paragraph: 7:15 P.M. (HBO) HALF PAST AUTUMN: THE LIFE AND WORKS OF GORDON PARKS (2000). Parks (right), who died last Tuesday at 93, was the first black photographer on Life magazine's masthead, the director of ''Shaft,'' an author, an artist, a musician and a poet. This film, narrated by Alfre Woodard, begins with Parks's early childhood in Kansas and follows him through a truly remarkable life and career. 6 P.M. TO MIDNIGHT (Discovery Health) BIRTH DAY LIVE -- This annual reality-programming event aims for new heights of intrusiveness by posing lame questions to women in agonizing labor pain, doctors busy guiding infants down the birth canal and panicked husbands obligated to be in the delivery room. (''Has your wife been enjoying this second pregnancy?'' a perky reporter asked in last year's edition.) This year's show comes live from hospitals in San Diego; Baton Rouge, La.; and Silver Spring, Md. This may be educational television, but it seems a shame when the doctors hold the newborns up for the cameras before they show them to the mothers, who have done all that hard work. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS -- A teenage boy attaches a bomb to his body and holds his fellow high school students hostage. The question is whether this was his idea. 8 P.M. (5) AMERICAN IDOL -- Week 9. The 12 finalists perform. 9 P.M. (ABC) SONS & DAUGHTERS -- In the evening's first episode, young Henry (Trevor Einhorn, left) tries to talk his family out of attending his school film festival. For good reason. Then, at 9:30, a big family barbecue turns into something of a group therapy session. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- Recently, Brad Chase (Mark Valley) helped out his colleague Paul Lewiston (Rene Auberjonois) by spying on his daughter (Jayne Brook), who claims to have kicked her meth habit. Now Paul asks for more of Brad's help. Meanwhile, as if Alan Shore (James Spader) doesn't have enough problems, his secretary (Marisa Coughlan) is arrested for tax evasion. 10 P.M. (FX) THE SHIELD -- ''Of Mice and Lem.'' Vic (Michael Chiklis) may be a corrupt cop, but he tries to take care of his people. Concerned about Lem (Kenneth Johnson) being safe in prison, he makes a deal with the Devil, so to speak, to protect him. 10 P.M. (USA) NASHVILLE STAR -- Season premiere. As the title pretty much spells out, this is a show in which would be country music singers compete. Wynonna Judd (right) and Cowboy Troy are the hosts. Big & Rich, who will perform tonight, are among the judges. ANITA GATES

docs.lead_paragraph: My Neighbor Totoro The Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki first attracted attention in the West with this 1988 feature, a gentle, haunting fantasy rooted, as the best fantasy films are, in a strict psychological realism. When their mother's illness and their father's new job force them to move to a village in the countryside, two little girls find an answer to their sudden sense of estrangement and abandonment when they meet the title character, a forest spirit who takes the form of a huge, perpetually startled hamster. Though the film has long been available in various video editions, the Walt Disney Company has now reissued it in a bright and beautiful widescreen transfer that offers a choice between the original Japanese soundtrack and a newly produced English version, featuring the voices of Dakota Fanning and her sister, Elle.
docs.abstract: Dave Kehr Critic's Choice article recommends DVD's of My Neighbor Totoro, The Thing Called Love, Zu Warriors and Dog Eat Dog; photos (M)
docs.snippet: New releases include the Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki's "My Neighbor Totoro" and a director's cut of Peter Bogdanovich's "Thing Called Love," starring River Phoenix.

docs.abstract: Letter from Drs Abraham L Halpern and Barbara E O'Connell on shackling of prisoners in labor reports that even least dangerous inmates are subjected to painful restrictions when taken to outside prisons
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Giving Birth in Chains'' (editorial, March 5):

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like the setup of a joke: 20 rabbis walk into a fertility clinic. But it really happened. One recent Tuesday afternoon in Brooklyn, a group of young men in yarmulkes packed the waiting room of the Genesis Fertility Center, eyes glued to a roundish smudge on a video screen, absorbing a lecture in basic reproductive technology.

headline.main: Rabbis Train for Questions About Fertility Medicine

docs.abstract: Group of 20 rabbis, all graduate students at Yeshiva University, attend course at Jewish law at Genesis Fertility Center in Brooklyn, where they learn of latest advances in reproductive technology and study e their consequences under Jewish law; photo (M)
docs.snippet: "This is stuff that comes up every day," said course instructor Rabbi Kenneth Brander, a dean at Yeshiva University.

docs.lead_paragraph: The phone rang in Linda Doucett's desert ranch house here in the late spring of 1998. It was her ex-fiancé, the comedian Garry Shandling, calling. Again. Mr. Shandling had called several times that year to talk about his lawsuit accusing Brad Grey, his longtime manager and friend, of enriching himself at his expense. Now he was asking Ms. Doucett to testify for him.

headline.main: A Studio Boss and a Private Eye Star in a Bitter Hollywood Tale

docs.snippet: Prosecutors are trying to determine which of Anthony Pellicano's clients knew about the acts that have led to his indictment.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER and ALLISON HOPE WEINER

docs.lead_paragraph: Like most American women who give birth to a severely handicapped child, Donna Branca became pregnant with A.J. well before the age of 35. Had she been older, her doctors would almost certainly have recommended amniocentesis to screen for genetic disorders. But she was 31, so they did not, despite the fact that she had an unusual pregnancy. Branca bled during her first trimester, a possible indication of birth defects, and at her midterm sonogram, when she was 20 weeks pregnant, her fetus looked smaller than it should have based on when her doctors originally presumed she conceived. Branca had not gained much weight, either, but her doctors -- whom she is barred from identifying, by a legal settlement -- saw no cause for alarm. ''Looking back now, of course, it's easy to say I should have asked more questions or maybe been a little more concerned,'' she told me last fall, sitting in her grassy backyard in Orangeburg, 20 miles north of Manhattan. Branca is a pretty woman, dark and compact, with a winning suburban New York accent. She glanced at A.J., a 6-year-old with a head of dark curls and the mental capacity of a 6-month-old. Her 3-year-old twins from a subsequent pregnancy ran around collecting acorns.
docs.abstract: Elizabeth Weil article on wrongful-birth lawsuits being brought by parents of severely disabled children against obstetricians whom they accuse of failing to provide kind of prenatal screening and care that would have allowed them to consider having abortions; says lawsuits reflect relatively new belief that people should have right to choose which babies are born; focuses on lawsuit brought by Donna and Anthony Branca of Orangeburg, NY, who won multimillion-dollar settlement set aside for care of a son born with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Legally, and morally, what does it mean to say that a child should not have existed?
